content.raw: The preceding code comment does not make it clear to me what this line should do. In any case, I don’t observe different behaviour with this change, i.e. in both cases I see new columns added to the table \(e.g. when a shot is added with a newly created global\), and this global is checked as visible in the ‘Edit visible columns’ dialog.

content.raw: Ah, you are correct. This is redundant because the column visibility is already being updated when the column is added earlier in the function. I’ll just remove this block then.

content.raw: Since you don’t have commit access to my fork, Bitbucket didn’t allow you to close the branch when merging, so I pushed an extra 2 commits to close it. I’ll give you commit access to my forks when making future pull requests to avoid leaving branches open, but if you don’t see the ‘close branch’ checkbox when merging, let me know.
content.html: Since you don’t have commit access to my fork, Bitbucket didn’t allow you to close the branch when merging, so I pushed an extra 2 commits to close it. I’ll give you commit access to my forks when making future pull requests to avoid leaving branches open, but if you don’t see the ‘close branch’ checkbox when merging, let me know.

content.raw: If you check the ‘close branch after pull request is merged’ option when creating the pull request, the person doing the merge doesn’t need commit access to the fork \(or to do anything else when merging?\).
content.html: If you check the ‘close branch after pull request is merged’ option when creating the pull request, the person doing the merge doesn’t need commit access to the fork (or to do anything else when merging?).

content.raw:
[Unfortuntely not](https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issues/14116/mercurial-cross-fork-pullrequests-dont).

'Close branch' closes it on the source fork before merging, it does not close it on the destination fork. You would think it could do either, but it does not. If the merger doesn’t have permissions to the source fork, they don’t see the checkbox and the branch doesn’t get closed.  
  
As far as I can tell, me checking the box just sets what the default value of the checkbox you will see is when you merge it, if you have permissions, otherwise you see no such checkbox when you merge.
content.html:
Unfortuntely not.

'Close branch' closes it on the source fork before merging, it does not close it on the destination fork. You would think it could do either, but it does not. If the merger doesn’t have permissions to the source fork, they don’t see the checkbox and the branch doesn’t get closed.

As far as I can tell, me checking the box just sets what the default value of the checkbox you will see is when you merge it, if you have permissions, otherwise you see no such checkbox when you merge.
